description: From Middle English tare (“vetch”), from Old English *taru, from Proto-West Germanic *taru.

entries.meaning: (rare) A vetch, or the seed of a vetch (genus Vicia, esp. Vicia sativa)
Any of the tufted grasses of genus Lolium; darnel.
(rare, figuratively) A damaging weed growing in fields of grain.
examples: But while men slept, his enemy came and sowed tares among the wheat, and went his way.

description: Middle French tare, from Italian tara, from Arabic طَرْحَة‎ (ṭarḥa, “that which is thrown away”), a derivative of طَرَحَ‎ (ṭaraḥa, “to throw (away)”).

entries.meaning: The empty weight of a container; unladen weight.
examples: What is the neat weight of 4 hogsheads of tobacco, each weighing 10cwt. 3qrs. 10lb. gross; — tare 100lb. per hdd.?

verbs.description: tare (third-person singular simple present tares, present participle taring, simple past and past participle tared)

entries.meaning: (chiefly business and law) To take into account the weight of the container, wrapping etc. in weighting merchandise.
examples: he is  […]  to tare such number of bales as may be deemed necessary to settle the net weight for duty.

entries.meaning: (sciences) To set a zero value on an instrument (usually a balance) that discounts the starting point.
examples: Spectrometers, for example, must be zeroed before each reading; balances must be tared before each weighing.

description: Borrowed from Japanese 垂(た)れ (tare, “sauce, gravy”).

entries.meaning: Any of various dipping sauces served with Japanese food, typically based on soy sauce.
